utterances: And what the weather might be like that day.
I hear it's rather cold in your neck of the woods that time of year.
Yeah, it's 37 degrees, I've read, average for that day.
And it depends also on who you're with, love the one you're with.
It's not like a mosh pit at a rock concert, but it will be close.
Professor El-Baz likes to plot this out using square meters.
This is when I assumed that you would have something like six people per square meter.
This is the very close packing, and some people will be touching each other.
Their arms will be right next to each other, which is OK.
(Laughing) He says it's OK.
The professor - he made his crowd counting reputation by analyzing - remember the Million Man March back in 1995, controversial deal(ph)?
Oh, yeah, anytime there's any kind of march or protest, there's always debate about how many people are actually there.
Yeah, he came in after the fact, looked at the photographs, and he said, 878,587.
That's a very precise number.
Yeah, that's his number.
He's sticking to it.
He does say there was a margin of error of 20 percent.
Now, let's get back to this idea of the inauguration, six people to a square meter.
I went to the Mall, as I said.
I took along some orange tape.
I put it out on the ground, and I made a square meter.
And sure enough, here comes a family.
I said, can you see if you can fit inside the square meter?
So I laid out my tape.
I laid out my proposition.
They were so curious they had to go along.
They couldn't resist.
All right, let's try it.
My hips are too big.
How many...
OK.
What size people do you want?
Just six - that's what he said.
Was this an average sized family?
Were you able to fit them all in that square?
Well, yeah, almost.
You can hear this.
All right, one, two...
Three, four, five...
Five, six.
Very cozy, very cozy.
This is the Minnick family from nearby in Virginia.
Aspen(ph), Amber(ph), Jolen(ph), Madison(ph) and Todd(ph), plus a visiting grandmother Adel Lavson(ph).
Alex, the size of the square meter, to envision this, is like a refrigerator - same space a refrigerator takes up - or maybe the size of a baby's playpen.
Now, we took a picture of the family inside, and here it is.
You can see it on the NPR Web site.
Now, I'm looking at this picture here, and there's one slight problem.
The Minnick family's in the square with the exception of the baby, there's no room.
No inauguration for little tiny infant Minnick?
Well, the baby is in a stroller.
Baby has to be outside the square.
Well, anyway, maybe they could stick the baby inside.
It depends on how long they have to stand there.
The question really is, is the Minnick family coming to the inauguration?
They got into a discussion about that.
I can't - I don't like crowds.
I would not do it.
It would be...
I don't like crowds...
The positive thing is people will be warm...
No, I don't like crowds even for that...
It's an event that, it's going to be very historical.
So you hear Mr. Minnick there saying it could be warm.
Is that because they're all snuggled in so tight together?
Yes, squishy.
They've got the big coats on, big winter coats, though.
I think they will be watching on television.
They'll be watching the two to three million people who have a real-life view of inauguration and that very real sense of being at that place at that moment.
(As Kevin Richardson) I don't want to be here.
I want to go home.
We were told not to expect anything beyond two or three years.
One doctor actually said he would be a vegetable within two years.
He was a jerk.
But this was before--I mean, this was just at the beginning of Aricept and before Exelon and any of the other drugs.

And because he had early onset, which they felt would progress faster than the type you get as you age, that he just would not be able to be functioning at all; that I should make arrangements right away for nursing homes, for care.
And there's no way I'm going to plan something that far in advance.
I mean, I don't know when I'm going to need to do anything.
I don't know when he's going to need full-time help at home, 'cause I would like for him to stay at home as long as he remembers home.
I think that's very important.
But I am going to need help eventually, and it's going to be very difficult because he's not going to be very accepting as well.
Yes, I will.
I have now.
You say you are accepting of it now, Tom?
Yeah.
I can't do anything with it.
I just have somebody to take me around.
Joyce, I wonder if that's been a hard adjustment to make, to...
Very.
...something that would seem so finite maybe that's become much more protracted for you, for you both.
Yeah, well, either way, it's not a good scenario.
Sure.
But I have--I was used to being more independent.
And now I'm not; I'm pretty trapped.
Not his fault at all--I just haven't been able to adjust as well as I think I should have.
My depression was very severe...
Yeah.
And it's still pretty severe.
But I still haven't found a way to manage in my brain.
With what's going on, you mean?
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
